answers.author: Peter Dunn
answers.text:
There was an article in the Wall Street Journal this week about several such merger studies that suggest that mergers often fail to save and may even raise costs. Labor costs are not typically reduced by consolidation, and larger jurisdictions require more expensive professional staff. Some specific services, however, can benefit from economies of scale.
http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424053111904875404576532342236074926.html

answers.text:
Here's a copy of a preliminary consolidation study prepared and funded by a private business group I am a member of that is being used to set the stage for a larger formal consolidation process.  It did not review the Police dept's which were at the same time going through a consolidation study already.  It also did not look at the water and sewer utility authority for one of the communities since it is not part of their municipal government.  Hope this helps.
